body_content.explanation: in or towards a low or lower position, from a higher one:
examples: Is this lift going down?
Don't look down! You'll get dizzy.
The sun's going down and it'll be dark soon.
The space capsule came down in the ocean.
I bent down to look under the bed.

body_content.explanation: moving from above and onto a surface:
examples: Just as I was sitting down to watch TV, the phone rang.
Why don't you lie down on the sofa for a while?
This box is really heavy - can we put it down (on the floor) for a minute?
Get down off that table immediately!
The terrorists forced everybody to lie face down (= with the front part of the body below) on the floor.

body_content.explanation: firmly in place or into position:
examples: I put the loose floorboard back and nailed it down.
He held my arms down by my sides.

body_content.explanation: in or towards a lower level, a smaller amount, or a simpler state:
examples: The rate of inflation is finally going down.
Turn the TV down - it's way too loud!
The nurse bandaged my sprained ankle to keep the swelling down (= to limit the swelling).
If you wait a few months, the price will come down.
The Cavaliers were 20 points down (= losing by 20 points) at half-time.
The number of students at this school has gone down from 500 last year to 410.

body_content.explanation: If you burn, cut, or knock something or someone down, you cause it, him, or her to fall to the ground, usually damaged, destroyed, or injured:
examples: The house burned down many years ago.
These trees will have to be cut down to make way for the new road.
She was knocked down by a car and killed instantly.

body_content.explanation: in writing or on paper:
examples: I'll write it down now so I won't forget.
Do you have it down in writing/on paper, or was it just a verbal agreement?
I've got/put you down for (= have written that you want) three tickets each.
The police officers were taking down the names of witnesses.

body_content.explanation: used, especially with prepositions, to emphasize that a place is at some distance from you or from somewhere considered to be central:
examples: I'll meet you down at the gym after work.
He has a house down by the harbour.
I'm going down to the shop to buy some milk.

body_content.explanation: in or towards the south:
examples: It's much warmer down (in the) south.
My parents live down in Florida, but they come up to Chicago every summer.
We're moving down to London.

body_content.explanation: from an older person to a younger one:
examples: The necklace has been passed/handed down through seven generations.
These myths have come down to us from prehistoric times.

body_content.explanation: inside your stomach:
examples: You'll feel better once you've got some hot soup down you.
He's getting weak because he can't keep anything down.

body_content.explanation: at the time of buying:
examples: I gave him $1,000 down, and paid the rest in instalments.

body_content.explanation: in or towards a low or lower position, from a higher one:
examples: I slid down the hill.
Aikiko fell down some stairs and broke her wrist.

body_content.explanation: along:
examples: We drove down the highway as far as Atlanta.
Her office is down the corridor on the right.
They sailed the boat down the river (= towards the sea).

body_content.explanation: to:
examples: I went down the pub with my mates.

body_content.explanation: to cause something or someone to fall to the ground:
examples: We downed three enemy planes with our missiles.
The ice storm has downed trees and power lines all over the region.

body_content.explanation: to eat or drink something quickly:
examples: He'd downed four beers before I'd finished one.

body_content.explanation: to defeat someone, especially in sport:
examples: The Yankees downed the Red Sox 7–0.

body_content.explanation: unhappy; unable to feel excited or energetic about anything:
examples: She's been really down since her husband left.
I've been (feeling) a little bit down this week.

body_content.explanation: (of a system or machine, especially a computer) not in operation or not working, usually only for a limited period of time:
examples: The network will be down for an hour for routine maintenance.
The whole system's gone down.

body_content.explanation: in American football, a player is down when he is brought to the ground by an opponent while holding the ball, before having reached the goal:
examples: The referee ruled that the running back was down at the 44-yard line.
The replay showed that the player was never down, so the play should have continued.

body_content.explanation: small soft feathers, especially those from a young bird:
examples: goose/duck down
a down jacket/pillow/sleeping bag (= a jacket/pillow/sleeping bag filled with down)

body_content.explanation: very soft thin hair
in American football, one of four chances that a team is given to advance the ball ten yards towards the goal:
examples: They needed to gain three more yards to get a first down.
On fourth down, the coach had to decide whether to punt, attempt a field goal, or try for a touchdown.

body_content.explanation: to dislike someone, often unfairly:
examples: Why do you have a down on him? I think he seems really nice.

body_content.explanation: at or towards the end or the lower or worse part:
examples: downhill
downriver
down-market
the downside

body_content.explanation: a county (= an area with its own local government) in the southeast of Northern Ireland:
examples: Tommy visited Peter in Newry, County Down, just a few weeks ago.
He married a girl from the Co Down town where he grew up.
